Pros:
Disclaimer: A lot of what I'm writing below of course depends on the work area and management chain.  But I found this to be fairly pervasive policies in IBM in my 9+ years with the company. 
1. IBM's policies and management are very flexible when it comes to working remotely or accommodating various life situations (sick days, doctor visits, etc.).  Management is encouraged to measure an employee by their work and impact, and not by hours spent at their office. 
2. Great colleagues!  Though unfortunately, many have been leaving due to the instability of IBM's HW development business. 
3. At least in my area, there's a high level of flexibility on which projects should I undertake based on my and my management assessment of business impact.
Cons:
1. Unfortunately, IBM still uses the "normal distribution" rating system, where at the end of the year each employee is ranked as a top contributor (5%), above average contributor (15%), average contributor (~75%), and bottom contributor (5%).  This curve is difficult to apply in the R&D world, where you may have many members of the team working long and hard hours, and end up being "average contributors" at the end of the year, because there just isn't room for all to be top contributors. 

2. The above may not be so disturbing, if only IBM didn't practically cancelled all raises, performance bonuses and incentive for the non top-performers. I've had a consistent "above average" rating in the last 4-5 years, and my raise and performance bonus were ridiculous mere 1.5-2% of my salary.  Were I rated "average contributor" I would have gotten NOTHING. So you can imagine that people can go year after year without any raise to their salary.

From talking to manager friend, this is IBM's way to eliminate the non-top-performers without having to fire them, as part of its direction of reducing US manpower. 

3. Hiring freeze in many areas - again, as part of IBM's attempt to reduce its workforce across North America and Europe we see many jobs move to the India and Far East markets.  This is of course upsetting to see local teams shrink and disappear, especially when many great local IBM colleagues and experts begin to drop out. From my experience thus far working with India SW teams - they are still very far away from the standards I would have expected from US and Europe based teams. 

4. Poor top down communication about company's and divisions' future.  Employees learn from rumors and news websites what's about to come...

3x/week mandate is unnecessary especially since many cross functional teams aren't co-located anyway.

Working at IBM as a Full Stack Software Engineer was a valuable and enriching chapter in my professional journey. The company offers a unique blend of enterprise stability with a constant push for innovation, especially in areas like cloud computing, AI, and hybrid technologies.

Team & Culture
IBM fosters a collaborative and inclusive environment. I had the opportunity to work alongside talented engineers, product managers, and designers from diverse backgrounds. The culture encourages continuous learning, knowledge sharing, and creative problem-solving, which made for an engaging work atmosphere.

Projects & Impact
During my time at IBM, I worked on end-to-end development of scalable web applications, contributing to both frontend and backend components. I was involved in designing APIs, implementing user interfaces with modern frameworks like React, and building backend services using Node.js. The projects were challenging yet rewarding, and I appreciated how the work directly impacted clients and internal tools at scale.

Learning & Growth
IBM invests significantly in employee development. I had access to a wide range of internal resources, mentorship opportunities, and certification programs. I enhanced my skills in cloud-native technologies, DevOps practices, and agile methodologies. The experience helped me grow both technically and professionally.

Challenges
Like many large organizations, IBM can sometimes have slower decision-making processes due to its scale and structure. Navigating legacy systems alongside modern stacks posed occasional challenges, but it also provided valuable lessons in system integration and refactoring.

**Overall**  
My experience at IBM was overwhelmingly positive. It was a great place to sharpen my full stack skills, work on meaningful projects, and collaborate with intelligent and driven colleagues. I left with a strong foundation in enterprise software development and a deep appreciation for IBM’s commitment to innovation and excellence.
Cons: One of the notable challenges at IBM was navigating the bureaucracy that comes with working at a large, legacy enterprise. Decision-making processes could be slow, with multiple layers of approvals often required even for relatively minor changes. This occasionally hampered agility and made it harder to quickly implement innovative ideas or respond to changing requirements. While there’s a strong emphasis on process and compliance—which is understandable at IBM’s scale—it sometimes created friction for fast-paced development and experimentation.

Pros: I like the people on the teams I manage. Over 22+ years I've worked with some great people.
Cons:
The days of the "IBMer" are over. Over the past year and a half, IBM leaders have gone from being ambivalent to being openly hostile towards employees. They eliminated 401k match, eliminated remote work (including for employees who were remote prior to the pandemic), implemented return to office mandates regardless of job role and team structure, conducted multiple layoffs (including three in 2024 and one so far in 2025), forced relocation to high cost locations with the goal of getting older people with families to quit, eliminated employee-friendly perks and benefits, changed the annual employee assessment program multiple times (and now returned to a forced-rank system where 20% of all employees are required to be identified as low performers), stopped all employee spending (including office supplies, keyboard/mouse, travel, etc. Multiple cases of employees being told by their managers to pay for work-related travel out of their own pockets), annual promotion cycle cancelled for two straight years, and the list goes on.

The 2025 GDP and ESP programs (bonus and annual salary increase) were rigged to skip older employees regardless of their 2024 performance ratings ($0 for both bonus and annual salary increase). This was mandated by senior leadership and is blatant age discrimination (which IBM has been successfully sued for multiple times).

There is an aggressive plan to move a significant portion of jobs to India and other "low cost" countries. This is ongoing and is planned to continue for the next three years. It will impact employees in all parts of IBM.

Most people I work with come to work every day feeling fear, anxiety, and depression. For all of us, the question isn't "if" but "when" we will lose our jobs. And there's nothing anyone can do about it - being a top performer, working extra hours, taking on more projects, etc. do not provide any protection.

Even though I still work at IBM (and have for over 20 years), I can no longer recommend IBM as a place that anyone would wish to work. If you're considering coming here, do yourself a favor and DON'T.

- Supportive of LGBTQ+ employees in some ways, for example: can elect insurance coverage (at least in the US) for same sex partners (married or domestic partnership); insurance coverage for gender affirming care; choice of a variety of pronouns in HR systems and directory; management training on use of pronouns, micro aggressions, how to support a transitioning employee, etc

Pros: The legacy of great innovation still exists within small, siloed pockets of the large, albeit shrinking, company. Furthermore, IBM has a history of employing exceptionally smart and talented individuals. Finally, IBM has been hiring more young talent as a way to not only save money (less expensive staff) but also to build a new cadre of talented IBMers.
Cons:
IBM, once a dominant force in the tech industry, has experienced a decline in its leadership position over the past few decades. While the company has invested heavily in emerging technologies like AI and quantum computing, its strategic decisions and organizational culture have contributed to its challenges.
IBM's revenue peaked in 2012 at $104.5 billion and has since declined to $61.86 billion in 2023.
IBM has a history of significant layoffs, often targeting experienced and high-performing employees. These layoffs can lead to a loss of institutional knowledge and innovation, hindering the company's ability to adapt to changing market conditions. In 2023 alone, IBM announced layoffs of around 3,900 employees, with plans for further cuts involving 8,000 roles by automating positions through AI. In 2024, thousands more senior skilled staff were laid off who were in the Band 10 (the highest pay grade before Executive pay bands) pay range in order to reduce expensive, talented employees in an effort to artificially boost the company's profits.
 IBM’s network and firmware are often outdated, with some software no longer supported by vendors. This reliance on aging tech infrastructure, compounded by offshoring, has made it harder for IBM to implement updates or compete effectively on cutting-edge services.
IBM’s commitment to AI and quantum computing, while substantial, has struggled to yield competitive financial returns, partly due to the company’s conservative approaches to AI applications, cost-focused layoffs, and reliance on outdated infrastructure.
Large amounts of technical debt and aging infrastructure prove difficult to connect shared data sources, leading to multiple "sources of truth" for data, which degrades the IBMer's ability to be efficient and highly productive.
Finally, while IBM was a pioneer in cloud computing, it was slow to adopt a cloud-first strategy, allowing competitors like Amazon Web Services and Microsoft Azure to gain significant market share.

Pros:
1. Innovation and Cutting-Edge Technology
Pioneering in AI, Cloud, and Quantum Computing: IBM is at the forefront of emerging technologies such as artificial intelligence (AI), hybrid cloud, and quantum computing. Employees have the chance to work on groundbreaking projects and be part of industry-defining advancements.
Commitment to Research and Development: IBM invests heavily in R&D, giving employees opportunities to work with cutting-edge tools, technologies, and methodologies.
2. Career Development and Learning Opportunities
Continuous Learning Culture: IBM offers extensive training and certification programs, including access to IBM’s learning platform, which covers a wide range of skills from technical to leadership development.
Career Growth: IBM has a global presence and offers numerous opportunities for career advancement, enabling employees to transition into different roles, departments, or regions.
3. Global Reach and Diverse Workforce
Global Company: With a presence in over 170 countries, IBM provides the opportunity to work on global projects, collaborate with international teams, and even relocate to different parts of the world.
Diversity and Inclusion: IBM is deeply committed to fostering a diverse and inclusive workplace, promoting equal opportunities for all, and supporting various Employee Resource Groups (ERGs).
4. Work-Life Balance and Flexibility
Remote Work Options: IBM has embraced hybrid and remote work models, allowing for greater flexibility in where and how employees work.
Focus on Well-Being: IBM offers programs to support physical, mental, and emotional well-being, including wellness programs, mental health support, and financial wellness planning.
5. Corporate Social Responsibility
Commitment to Sustainability: IBM has ambitious sustainability goals and is actively involved in projects aimed at reducing its environmental footprint.
Social Impact Initiatives: IBM encourages employees to participate in initiatives that give back to the community, such as volunteer programs, mentorship opportunities, and social impact projects.
6. Strong Employee Benefits
Comprehensive Benefits Package: IBM offers competitive salaries, performance-based bonuses, and comprehensive healthcare plans, including dental and vision coverage.
Retirement and Savings Plans: IBM provides generous retirement benefits, including 401(k) plans with employer matching contributions.
Paid Time Off and Parental Leave: Employees enjoy paid vacation time, personal leave days, and robust parental leave policies for both primary and secondary caregivers.
7. Company Stability and Legacy
Longstanding Legacy: As a company over 100 years old, IBM is a stable and established organization, providing job security and the ability to learn from its rich history of technological innovation.
Trusted Brand: IBM’s brand is well-regarded globally, making it a prestigious company to work for, enhancing your career credibility and future opportunities.
8. Collaborative and Innovative Work Culture
Cross-Disciplinary Collaboration: At IBM, employees frequently collaborate across departments and specializations, working with teams from software development, cloud services, research, and more to solve complex problems.
Empowering Work Environment: IBM encourages a culture of autonomy and responsibility, where employees are empowered to make decisions, innovate, and push the boundaries of technology.
Working at IBM provides opportunities to contribute to high-impact projects, grow professionally, and be part of a dynamic global team.
Cons:
1. Bureaucracy and Slow Decision-Making
Large Company Structure: As a massive, global organization with over 350,000 employees, IBM can sometimes suffer from slow decision-making processes and bureaucratic hurdles. It can take time to get approvals or push through initiatives, which may frustrate employees looking for agility and speed in their work.
Complex Organizational Layers: The multi-layered hierarchy may make it difficult to implement changes or navigate internal structures.
2. Frequent Restructuring and Layoffs
Ongoing Restructuring: IBM has undergone several rounds of restructuring and realignment in recent years to focus on cloud computing and AI. While this shift is strategic, it has led to frequent layoffs and uncertainty in certain divisions.
Job Security Concerns: Due to these periodic layoffs, employees may feel insecure about their positions, particularly in legacy business units like hardware or traditional IT services.
3. Compensation and Raises
Slow Salary Growth: Some employees report that salary increases and promotions can be slow to materialize, particularly when compared to competitors in the tech industry. Merit-based raises are sometimes modest, despite high performance.
Below-Average Pay in Some Regions: Depending on location and role, IBM's base salary may not always be competitive with other major tech companies, especially for junior or mid-level employees.
4. Work-Life Balance
Long Hours in Some Roles: While IBM does offer remote and flexible work options, some employees, particularly in client-facing or high-pressure roles, report long hours and heavy workloads. The balance between work and personal life can be challenging in certain departments.
Global Teams: Employees working with international teams may have to deal with time zone differences, leading to meetings or tasks outside of standard working hours.
5. Legacy Systems and Technology
Outdated Technology in Certain Areas: Despite its focus on innovation, IBM still has divisions dealing with older, legacy systems and technologies. Working on these systems may not be as exciting or fulfilling for employees looking to engage with cutting-edge projects.
Transition to Cloud: IBM is still in the process of pivoting to become a cloud-first company. Some teams are caught between maintaining legacy systems and transitioning to modern platforms, which can be difficult to navigate.
6. Pace of Innovation
Slow Adoption of New Technologies: In some cases, IBM's size and bureaucracy can slow down the adoption of newer technologies or agile practices, making it harder to keep up with fast-moving trends in the tech industry.
Resistance to Change: Legacy teams or more traditional areas of the company may resist newer, more modern methods of working, such as DevOps or agile practices, which can frustrate employees looking to innovate.
7. Limited Career Advancement
Limited Mobility in Certain Divisions: While IBM offers many training and learning opportunities, some employees report that career advancement can be slow, especially in non-technical or support roles.
Competition for Promotions: Due to the company's size, competition for leadership roles or promotions can be stiff, and upward mobility may be more challenging in saturated areas.
8. Complex Internal Tools and Processes
Complicated Internal Systems: Employees have reported that internal systems (such as HR tools, approval workflows, and internal communication platforms) can be outdated or overly complex, which can hamper productivity.
Inefficient Processes: Navigating IBM’s processes, from project management to performance evaluations, may feel inefficient, especially compared to more streamlined, agile environments in smaller companies.
9. Focus on Legacy Clients
Older Client Base: Some employees may find that much of the company's business still revolves around maintaining legacy clients or contracts, particularly in industries like finance, government, or healthcare. This focus may limit exposure to exciting, new industries or projects.
10. Cultural Divide Across Teams
Varied Experience Based on Department: The culture at IBM can vary significantly from one department or location to another. Employees in newer, cloud-focused divisions might have a more dynamic, innovative environment compared to those in traditional, more bureaucratic areas.
International Differences: Because IBM is a global company, employees may experience cultural and communication differences when collaborating with teams in different countries.
